utterances: The student moves to the next blank leaving the previous unfilled.
So much life we cannot have or find or repeat, yet so much we have had and found.
I've made this mistake a hundred times, one thinks, preparing to make it again.
One day I'll get rid of these expensive painful shoes but not now, says another, scanning her closet.
Some things must resign themselves to becoming something else, champagne flat, the burning log ash, after the crash the runner walks with a cane, but some must accept they'll never change.
Stained tablecloth never unstained, mark permanent on the heart.
You pick up a clod to throw on the coffin lid but can't so turn away, dropping it in your pocket.

An Israeli air strike in Syria last month is still unexplained.
And the tensions that resulted from that strike, along with increased Israeli military exercises in the occupied Golan Heights, are sparking jitters along the Syrian-Israeli border.
NPR's Eric Westervelt paid a visit to the Golan and he sent this report.
A former Israeli military bunker atop Mount Bental, overlooking the shattered Syrian city of Kuneitra, now is a tourist attraction, complete with a restaurant and gift shop.
Kids clutching ice cream cones play in the trenches of the thick stone and concrete redoubt, moving amid cutout silhouettes of soldiers holding wooden rifles.
Since the 1973 Yom Kippur War, the Golan has been one of the Mideast's quietest borders.
But last summer's inconclusive war in neighboring Lebanon against Hezbollah sparked new jitters here.
And just days ago, again, on Yom Kippur, locals tending their vineyards and orchards were rattled by the sound of Israeli fighter jets over the Golan.
A Syrian MiG had suddenly disappeared from Israeli radar, prompting Israel to scramble planes in response.
Thirty-six-year-old Druze rancher Waffeck Ajamay was tending his cattle.
(Through translator) People were scared.
We hadn't heard the sounds of fighter planes over the Golan for a very long time.
I was out in the field and looked in the sky and saw the airplanes and thought it was very odd.
I was a little worried.
It turns out the Syrian jet had simply crashed in an accident.
The Israeli planes stood down.
But then last Friday, Israel again scrambled planes after Syrian helicopters reportedly flew too close to the border area.
The incidents underscore the still-tense atmosphere here underneath the ordinary routines of this rural setting.
These days, the rumble and dust from Israeli heavy military trucks, tanks and equipment are ever present.
(Soundbite of passing vehicle)
Many locals say it's the busiest militarily they've seen on the Golan in a decade.
Forty-three year old Gyora Chepelinski and his wife moved to a kibbutz or communal farm on the Golan six years ago from Argentina.
They opened a small chocolate factory near the base of Mount Avital, atop of which sits a key Israeli military post overlooking Syria.
There is a sensation that something is happened.
You don't know exactly what, but, yeah, it's very different from what happened here before the last time at war.
Many Israeli soldiers posted or who trained agree.
This Israel defense force reserve soldier agreed to speak only on condition his name not be used.
Now it's more tensed than ever.
Both sides are doing all the things that's supposed to make the other side feel not comfortable.
The Israeli soldier says he observed increased activity on the Syrian side of the border up-close during a recent month-long training exercise.
He says construction projects, long visible on the Syrian side, have expanded in recent months.
And lots of heavy machinery.
It looks like they do civilian work, but civilian work is the same.
I mean, if you dig out a trench for a cable, it going to be good against tanks, good for infantry.
It looks like they are getting ready.
Israel has significantly increased its military activity on the Golan this year.
After last summer's war with Hezbollah, Israel re-manned Golan lookout posts that had sat empty for years.
Israel also increased tank and infantry training exercises here.
Last week, the increase in activity prompted the commander of U.N.
Peacekeeping Forces on the Golan to voice concern.

Austrian Major General Wolfgang Jilke warned, in an interview with the German news magazine Der Spiegel, of a heightened risk of clashes breaking out due to the big increase in Israeli military training along the 45-mile-long U.N.-patrolled buffer zone.
Israeli military spokeswoman Captain Noa Meir says what the U.N.
general sees is normal.

Telling NPR, quote, ""it's no secret we need to get our army back in shape after last summer, these exercises are part of ongoing routine training."" But these Israeli solider says the exercises are bigger, more robust and very clear in their training mission.
We have like a big exercise on the Golan on going to Syria, like the breaking tanks defenses.
And lots more training with live fire.
It's more intensive than before.
In a BBC interview broadcast Monday, Syrian President Bashar al-Assad said his country reserves the right to retaliate for last month's Israeli air strike in northern Syria.
But Assad hinted a military response was not imminent.
He said the Israeli attack targeted a vacant military building.
President Assad also said Syria would not attend the American-sponsored Mideast peace meeting in November unless it addresses the occupation of the Golan, seized by Israel 40 years ago.
Eric Westervelt, NPR News, on the Golan Heights, Northern Israel.
Now, an update on the story of those devices that scared authorities and shutdown parts of Boston yesterday.

The one-foot tall signs we now know were part of an advertising campaign for a Cartoon Network show, ""Aqua Teen Hunger Force."" But their placement on bridges and other high-profile spots and their appearance - lighted circuit boards with wires and batteries - sparked fears of terrorism.
The devices were also found in nine other cities.
Boston's mayor says the stunt cost police more than $750,000.
And he's prepared to take legal action against Turner Broadcasting to get the money back.
Well today, the two men charged with putting up the devices in Boston were arraigned and released on bond after spending the night in jail.
